questions.question: Which side would you rather play in the following position (Black to move)?

answers.answer: White
Black

questions.question: When you play in tournaments, do you usually score with consistent results or do you often perform on the extremes - either really well or really poorly?

answers.answer: Pretty consistent results
Often perform either really well or really poorly

questions.question: Which best describes how you think about this position in the Sveshnikov Sicilian?

answers.answer: Black has given up a critically important square (d5).
Black has lots of potential counterplay with the bishop pair, and the f5 pawn break.

questions.question: Which statement is closer to the truth:

answers.answer: I bring my best game when facing opponents I dislike.
I don't really notice my opponent.

questions.question: Black has just played g5. Your first instinct is to...

answers.answer: Take on g5
Retreat to g3

questions.question: Do you play gambits?

answers.answer: Yes
No

questions.question: If given time to decide whether or not to take on g5 from the previous position, you would:

answers.answer: Know from the placement of the pieces if the black King would come under strong attack if it could be defended.
Calculate many variations to decide if White’s attack would be strong enough.

questions.question: Under serious time pressure you are more likely to:

answers.answer: Miss a tactic
Move pieces aimlessly

questions.question: Which of these ideas do you prefer for White?

answers.answer: White should trade bishops, and put an unassailable knight on d4, which will prevent any counterplay from black doubling rooks on the c-file by defending c2.
White should push d4, temporarily misplacing black's dark-squared bishop, and then start an attack on the kingside with f5 where the black king sits alone.

questions.question: You start the game out with 1.d4. Would you rather your opponent play 1...d5 or 1...f5?
You have been ahead a pawn for most of the game but after tough resistance from your opponent, you have only 5 minutes left in this position. Should you play on, or offer your opponent a draw?

answers.answer: Keep pushing for the win.
Offer a draw.

questions.question: Which statement comes closest to your feelings:

answers.answer: It's always a joy to be paired with someone you've crushed in the past.
The odds of winning are slightly higher against opponents one has previously beaten.

questions.question: In the following position with plenty of time on your clock, what would you do?

answers.answer: Trade on e6 and play Rd7 because the endgame is good for white or redirect the Knight to c3 (via a4) to preserve the better minor piece.
Invest some serious time calculating whether Nxe6 achieves anything concrete.

questions.question: What do you think of the famous saying "Chess is 99% Tactics."

answers.answer: I agree
I disagree

questions.question: How do you feel about this wild gambit line for Black?

answers.answer: No way - am I trying to lose?!
I like my chances and this will definitely mess with my opponent!

questions.question: After losing a game have you ever broken something or yelled out loud?

answers.answer: No
Yes

questions.question: White to play and castle...

answers.answer: Kingside
Queenside

questions.question: Which is closer to the truth:

answers.answer: I get excited or nervous before a game
I don't worry about prizes, money, titles, or honors while playing, I just play my game

questions.question: How would you come up with a plan in this position?

answers.answer: Consider the strengths and weaknesses of black's position, pick squares for my pieces, and open or close the position or maintain or increase central tension, based on those considerations.
I would calculate some plausible moves for white to see how strong various possibilities are.

questions.question: Which is harder for you to do?

answers.answer: Identify my advantages and building a plan
Trade a good position for a strong attack
